awd_titl_txt: Experimental Investigation of Mantle Heterogeneity: Behavior of Ga, Ge, and First-row Transition Elements (FRTE) During Partial Melting of Pyroxenite and Spinel Peridotite
awd_abstract_narration:
Earth's mantle is its largest layer by mass and volume and is ultimately the source of most of the magmas generated near Earth's surface. The chemistry and mineral composition of the rocks in Earth's mantle also serve as a time capsule that records events from the time of Earth's formation and its subsequent evolution caused by the recycling of near-surface materials back into the mantle through the processes of plate tectonics. This project is an experimental investigation of the chemistry of magmas that can be generated in Earth's mantle by different types of rocks that are likely to be found there. High pressure and high temperature experiments will be performed to investigate how the first-row transition elements (FRTE; Sc-Zn on the periodic table) and Ga and Ge behave during the formation of magmas in Earth's mantle. These elements are particularly useful for identify the types of rocks that may be melting to generate magmas. The results of this project will increase scientific knowledge of how magmas are formed on Earth and, through comparison with the chemistry of natural samples, will increase our understanding of the distribution of different rock types in Earth?s interior. Broader impacts of this research include support for an early-career researcher at a primarily undergraduate institution. The project will support training of a female graduate student who will gain expertise in formulating scientific questions, designing and performing experiments, analysis using several analytical methods, and interpretation and dissemination of experimental results. This project will also foster collaboration between the experimental lab at the University of Minnesota Duluth and the geochemistry and cosmochemistry lab at Florida State University, where analyses will be performed.

This research is an experimental study of the partitioning of FRTE between mantle minerals and melts, which will improve geochemical tools for identifying the source lithology of basaltic magmas. Experiments containing melts and either peridotite or pyroxenite mineral residues will be performed in a piston cylinder apparatus at conditions of mantle melt generation (pressures of 1.5 and 3 GPa and temperatures from 1270 to 1450 °C). These experiments will be doped with FRTE and Ga and Ge. The concentrations of these elements in the experimental run products (quenched melts and minerals) will be analyzed by laser ablation inductively-coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS). These analyses will yield partition coefficients for each element of interest between each mineral and coexisting melt. The project will aim to improve constraints on the concentrations and ratios of FRTE in melts generated by partial melting of peridotite and pyroxenite in Earth's mantle. Model melt compositions will be generated using these new experimental constraints and compared with the chemistry of natural basalts to better understand how lithological heterogeneity in the mantle is expressed in the chemistry of basaltic magmas. Better constraints on the source lithology of natural basalts will improve estimates of the abundance and distribution of recycled lithologies in Earth's upper mantle.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
This grant: Experimental Investigation of Mantle Heterogeneity: Behavior of Ga, Ge, and First-row Transition Elements (FRTE) During Partial Melting of Pyroxenite and Spinel Peridotite, supported an experimental investigation of how some key elements (most of which are present in the Earth's interior in concentrations of 10s to 1000s of parts per million) behave when rocks in Earth?s mantle partially melt to make basaltic magmas. These magmas can erupt on the surface as lavas along the mid-ocean ridges found at the bottoms of Earth's oceans and in volcanoes at the surface in places like Hawaii. The rocks that melt in the mantle are located so deep in the Earth, that they cannot be observed directly. The research project supported by this grant allows the combination of high-pressure and high-temperature experiments that simulate conditions in the deep Earth with chemical information from natural lavas found at Earth's surface to form a more complete picture of what is happening at depth. Experiments performed in this study provide information about the abundances of key elements expected to be found in lavas that melted from different kinds of rocks in the mantle, allowing the chemical measurements of the lavas to act as fingerprints that tell us about their source rocks.

Much of Earth's mantle is known to be made of a green rock called peridotite, which contains a large amount of the mineral olivine. Plate tectonic activity on Earth leads to other kinds of rocks from Earth's crust being returned to the mantle at subduction zones, places where tectonic plates sink back into the mantle. A significant proportion of the rocks returned to the mantle come from the oceanic crust. In the mantle, this crust becomes a rock called eclogite, which has blue-green minerals called pyroxene and red minerals called garnet. Past studies have revealed a lot about how the key elements in this study behave when peridotite melts, but less was known about melting eclogite. This study is especially about melting eclogites.

PI Dr. Fred Davis and master's student Andrew Regula, both at the University of Minnesota Duluth (UMD), performed experiments at the pressures found in the mantle and at temperatures hot enough to make magma in the laboratory. In the experiments they melted eclogites to form magmas and crystals of pyroxene and garnet. The experiments were cooled and then analyzed to learn about the chemistry of the minerals and magmas. They took pictures of the experiments using a scanning electron microscope at UMD to see what minerals grew and to make sure the minerals were big enough for chemical analysis. They traveled together to the University of Minnesota Twin Cities to use an electron microprobe to measure the compositions of major elements, such as silicon and iron, in the minerals and magmas. They traveled together to Florida State University to measure concentrations of the key elements, some of which were present in very small quantities (near 10 parts per million), in collaboration with Dr. Munir Humayun using LA-ICP-MS.

With measurements of the chemistry of the experimental minerals and magmas in hand, the researchers were able to calculate how much of each of the key elements would likely be found in magmas that were made by melting peridotite rocks or eclogite rocks. They found that ratios of the key elements, which previous studies had used to suggest that subducted crust played a large role in basalt formation in places like Hawaii, were misleading because the total concentrations of the elements in natural basaltic lavas were poorly matched by calculated compositions of magmas melted from eclogite or magmas that were mixtures between magmas from eclogites and magmas from peridotites. The researchers found concentrations of the key elements in most basaltic lavas are better explained by forming from magmas that melted from peridotite and then crystalized olivine minerals as they cooled. The results leave open the possibility that basalts could come from hybrid, in-between rocks that form when peridotites and eclogites are mixed together in the mantle before melting.

Andrew Regula reported results of the experiments in his master's thesis at UMD and presented the work at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting in 2019. The experiences in this project helped prepare Andrew Regula for his current position as a PhD student at the University of Chicago, where he continues to perform experiments and chemical analysis to learn more about the Earth?s interior. The researchers are preparing the results of the study for publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal.

 


Last Modified: 12/20/2021
Modified by: Frederick A Davis
